docs.lead_paragraph: Even when you don’t know it is Gertrude Stein in Picasso’s portrait (1905-1906), you can admire the work’s brush strokes, colors and composition. This poem is stunning even if you don’t know the back story. A declarative, compassionate, mysterious feeling radiates from turns of phrase like “Grace-panic. Warehorseman, split.” “The man you wore” rings as literal and figurative. But make no mistake: This magnificent poem only deepens when you learn Michael L. Johnson’s story. Read it, then reread it. Selected by Terrance Hayes

docs.abstract: A reinvention of the old standby with porcini butter and salsa verde.
docs.snippet: A reinvention of the old standby with porcini butter and salsa verde.
docs.lead_paragraph: I used to think I had a thing for old recipes. I’ve learned that this self-observation (like most of my impressions of myself) was wrong. I’ve actually followed “old recipes” probably twice. I once faithfully reproduced a “clam loaf.” I don’t know if it was my fault or the recipe’s, or maybe even the concept’s, but the result was inedible, and a little scary, and I arrived at the party I’d promised to bring it to holding a can of compensatory Spanish cockles. And I once made an antique “sauce piquant” with bone marrow, spooned it over a roast and coughed politely as murmurs round the table confirmed my impression that it tasted like old fish. We ate a lot of bread.

headline.main: Saving the Salisbury Steak From TV-Dinner Obscurity

docs.abstract: The former N.S.A. and C.I.A. chief on Trump, Snowden and what makes people leak secrets.
docs.snippet: The former N.S.A. and C.I.A. chief on Trump, Snowden and what makes people leak secrets.
docs.lead_paragraph: As the former director of the N.S.A. and the C.I.A. under George W. Bush, you’re part of a crop of ex-intelligence leaders who have recently joined the cable-news circuit. Why? We’re being talked about far more, so we need to have more of a direct dialogue. We’re not totally enthused by that. Secrecy is key to successful espionage.

docs.lead_paragraph: This breezy poem isn’t as breezy as it appears. Benign bubbles, sunbeams and kisses bounce among holes, necks on the block and wolves. Is it a coincidence that its end rhymes rhyme with squawk, for example? Its lines flit with an improvisatory gloss — another correlating rhyme. It might all be nursery rhyme were it not for the foreboding “too many” anaphora and the recurring “spoil” (with its toil and trouble). It’s a bewitching poem. A spell. Selected by Terrance Hayes

docs.abstract: Through memes and apparel, the far-right has found new ways to drum up racist sentiment, harking back to colonial Africa.
docs.snippet: Through memes and apparel, the far-right has found new ways to drum up racist sentiment, harking back to colonial Africa.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the sepia-toned photo, two white soldiers patrol on foot over brush and rocky ground. Lean and bearded, they carry what appear to be Belgian rifles, and they wear an unusual uniform — cloth jungle hats, short shorts and tennis shoes — associated with a military unit that was disbanded nearly 40 years ago.

headline.main: Rhodesia’s Dead — but White Supremacists Have Given It New Life Online

docs.abstract: It is the one holiday that grants permission to indulge in a spectacle of imagined global catastrophe.
docs.snippet: It is the one holiday that grants permission to indulge in a spectacle of imagined global catastrophe.
docs.lead_paragraph: Every few weeks, I wake up clammy from a dream in which I have failed to prepare myself for calamity. A frequent one has me flying down the freeway on cruise control when, out of nowhere, I decide to crawl into the back seat to grab something. I realize my mistake only as I feel the car begin to drift toward the median, but when I try to return to the front seat, my legs go limp. I always wake up before the crash.

docs.abstract: The ideal solution for a dessert with snap.
docs.snippet: The ideal solution for a dessert with snap.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last month, when I returned from a trip to China, I knew for sure that it would take me about 12 days to recover from having spent time in a place that was 12 hours ahead of home in New York. I resigned myself to a dozen mornings of waking up before dawn and just as many afternoons of finding myself fuzzy-headed at 4 and ready for bed soon after. What I didn’t anticipate were the fierce cravings that struck at all hours. Throughout the days and into some nights, I wanted both what I loved in China and what I missed while I was there. I dreamed of congee drizzled with vinegar, soup dumplings, slurpable noodles, tofu so fragile it wriggled off a spoon. But what I yearned for most was what I’d had least, sweets with crunch — lots of crunch, full-on crunch — a texture that hardly turned up in Shanghainese cooking.

headline.main: Nothing Satisfies the Need for Crunch Like Biscotti
